As summer winds down....

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎09-12-2014 10:51 AM

As the summer turns into fall, and then into winter, it is a good time to reflect on the current state of your D care. 

 

  1. If you are less active, you may need to change your i:c ratio
  2. If you spend less time outside tending things and more time at computers or TV, it might be time to put in a bit more exercise
  3. If you have procrastinated ratcheting up your care, time to get moving
  4. If you are already thinking about the holidays causing problems and you'll watch yourself after that, reset that brain
  5. If you've gotten lazy with your testing, pick it up

I'm a firm believer that there is low hanging fruit for all of us in improving our individual control to our individual standard.  I challenge you to find one thing to do better. 

 

For me, I will increase my exercise.



You go to school to learn, not for a report card.
You use your meter to learn, not for a report card

Type 1 (LADA).. Novolog/Levemir

Adult onset T1

‎09-12-2014 10:59 AM

Good post, Sun!

 

I will try to eat more veggies. Am still trying to get muscle mass built back up as well. I don't need a repeat of last winter. I am also getting my flu shot in October this year, rather than November.

 

Next.....

 

Trisha



Trisha

IDDM (Type 1 Autoimmune) 30+ many more years ~ Currently using MDI & Minimed CGM ~
Check out my diabetes blog!

All brittle means, is that one has great fluctuations, which is pretty much hallmark for Type 1's. Some more so than others. - me

First light brings a new day, new hope, new wisdom, and a chance to start fresh again. - me

If everyone were dealt the same amount of cards, there would be no challenges in life. Challenges are part of life's lessons, to teach us to grow in all aspects, and to learn what we need to learn, to make it in this world. Life was not meant to be fair. -me

"WE, the PEOPLE....."

~ New Type 1 Info ~ Insulin, Test Strips, Lancets, and other meds ~ Kidney Damage Info ~



*****************
Sidenote to new members....please put which type of diabetes you have, in your signature area. T1's and T2's cross post on these forums, and it is imperative that we all know which type one is. This is so that no misinformation is given to anyone. Type 1 and Type 2 are two totally absolute different diseases with different causes, thus making self-management very different. Thank you!, and welcome to the forums.
*****************

‎09-12-2014 10:14 PM

Gee, Sun.... for me, Fall and winter are a ratcheting up of activity.  Futbol season (that's soccer to you....) started about a week ago.  That means coaching practices during the week; coaching games on weekends; referreeing games on weekends.  When winter arrives, the games move indoors until spring... then it's outside again.  Then summer comes, and no more practices, no more games... just lazing around in the sun sipping martinis....

 

w.

Wayne T1 May 1966
MDI; 46u Lantus Basal

‎09-13-2014 07:34 PM - edited ‎09-13-2014 07:35 PM

I'll be cutting and splitting even more firewood since the temperatures are dropping.

And I'll need to remember to walk more at work. I also need to bring in the old NordicTrack and start using it again.

(I'm not co-ordinated enough to do the arms and legs at the same time*

 

Flu shots? I got my first one in 2011, when I was D'xd. Didn't get one last year, but I think I simply got lucky.

Might have to reconsider this year.

It seems like little things are upsetting my tightly controlled glucose levels more and more.....

‎10-12-2014 10:34 PM

eat more veggies and less of the carb/fat items. Fruits and veggies are made of a lot of water, so you could eat a large pile of veggies and it would be the same as eating one slice of cheese. Also fruits and veggies have a lot of vitamins in them so it will make your skin and hair nicer :-)

‎10-15-2014 11:39 AM

sunritef wrote:

As the summer turns into fall, and then into winter, it is a good time to reflect on the current state of your D care. 

 

{snip}

 

For me, I will increase my exercise.

Done that!... yesterday was a practice day.  As I noted above, I coach/referee soccer for my granddaughter's team.  Now, you're probably thinking "how hard can that be? For a bunch of 8 year olds??"  Well... it's tougher than you'd expect.  The soccer skills themselves are easy (since I played in college and have coached and refereed and managed teams for my own 3 kids), but the keeping up is more demanding.  They're little, and not hard to outplay, but when you spend an hour and a half running a field with a dozen kids, it starts to feel like work.  One of the drills we did was to practice "carrying" the ball.  By which I mean... running as fast as possible while "dribbling" the ball at your feet, without losing control of it or letting it get more than one pace away from you.  This skill is a tad beyond their skill level yet, but they're close.  And of course, you have to demonstrate... so while the other two (30 year younger) coaches watched, I got to lead the team around the field (an adult sized field) 3 times while "carrying" a ball.  Then, we did a variety of foot skills drills, and then played some games.  After practice, I got in the car, drove home, and then tried to get out of the car - NOPE!  EVERY muscle in my body was screaming at me!  Apparently, my summer of bumming around is coming back to haunt me... at this rate, by winter soccer time, if I'm not back in tip top shape, I'll be dead or crippled!!  

 

w.

 

"getting old lord, don't you know, is just a waste of time"... Chris Ledoux

Wayne T1 May 1966
MDI; 46u Lantus Basal
